*sigh* The first place to start is to learn some vocabulary. I am a hacker, but I do not infiltrate systems, nor do I try to steal confidential information, nor do I type feverishly at a keyboard in order to impress my friends. A hacker is an individual who loves to take things apart and see how they work. A hacker is an individual with boundless curiosity and an insatiable desire to ever expand their knowledge of the world, or at least a certain portion of it. Now, individuals who have this mindset can apply it in different ways. I apply it in the art of troubleshooting and building. I make a living at fixing complex problems and by making diverse and complicated systems internetwork. I find this very satisfying and it scratches the itch of my hacking tendencies. Others apply it to the "art" of infiltration, sabotage, and the circumvention of people's rights and liberties. It is these types that have been popularized in modern media and give individuals like myself a bad name. The professionals are generally paid by the mafia or by foreign governments to break the law for profit. Some do it purely out of curiosity and the need to prove superiority, while others do it because of base greed. I prefer to call these individuals "Crackers", a divergent sect of the Hacker culture. While I of course encourage you to pick the noble path of the hacker, you may be set on the course of becoming a cracker instead. Regardless, first ask yourself this question: Am I curious and stubborn to a fault? If yes, then you have a chance. As has been already stated by others, to "hack" you must learn. Spend your time reading RFCs, installing, configuring and operating every operating system out there, programming in as many languages as possible, building networks, and above all else... Never do anything the easy way. If there is a prepackaged software program, try to find the source and compile it for yourself. If an application has a GUI, try to find a command line alternative. If a programming problem can be solved by an API, write it from scratch yourself. If a software program has pre-built configuration files, delete them and build the config from scratch. It is not enough to know how to use a computer, network device, or piece of hardware, you must rather "know" it. Open it up, look at the working gears, compare it to other similar systems and draw parallels, figure out how it fits in the "big" picture. You get the idea. This almost always takes time. So much time that most give up. But if you train yourself to take the hard way, to spend the time to know, it will become easier. You'll have past knowledge that you can use to detect patterns, new systems will become transparent, and ultimately you'll learn the inspired axiom "there is no new thing under the sun."
